channel.title: R on Sina Rüeger
channel.description: Recent content in R on Sina Rüeger

item.title: Robust data analysis - an introduction to R
item.description: Course material for R introduction workshop held at Open science in practice summer school.

item.title: Amuse-bouches from useR!2019
item.description: The 3+ days at useR!2019 in Toulouse were packed with great talks1 and good food - hence the amuse-bouches word play. Here are some R code bits from the conference. Hopefully convincing enough to start using a new package or change a workflow. Not everything was brand-new, but it was helpful to have someone talking through their inspiration and examples. Check out the speakers’ materials - soon there will be recordings too.

item.title: R-package GWAS.utils
item.description: Helper functions when working with GWAS (summary) data.

item.title: R-package ggGWAS
item.description: ggplot2 extension for visualising GWAS summary statistics.

item.title: LD Part 1
item.description: Goal Two approaches Our toy data 1A. A solution that works: ldlink from NIH LDproxy LDmatrix 1B. A solution that almost works: ensembl.org What reference panels/population can we choose from? Access LD between a SNP and its region Access LD matrix Access LD between a SNP and many other SNPs Coloured locuszoom plot 2. Solutions that work half-through SNPsnap API provided by sph.umich 3. A solution that does not work rsnps::ld_search Conclusion Session Info R-packages used:

item.title: Create a map of the 1000 Genomes project reference populations
item.description: Goal Get started Data Add geographical coordinates Create leaflet Save the map Reason for deviation from the original This post provides the R-Code to map the 26 populations of the 1000 Genomes project. Goal Create a map similar to the one1 on the front page of http://www.internationalgenome.org/ in a reproducible manner. Version on internationalgenome.org Get started Packages needed:

item.title: Workflow & best practices for projects
item.description: Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

item.title: Tidying workflows in R
item.description: What is a “project folder”? Why now? Why we tidy up: authority and incentive Challenges What I want The options Drake Getting started More Examples Resources But wait: drake does not care about messy folders What is next? When is the right time to tidy Is it worth it? Recently, I started to seriously1 think about the tidiness of data analysis project folders and the implications of tidying up.
